DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says it Acted in Self-Defense in Panama
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said Wednesday the United States acted in self-defense when it sent its military forces to Panama to oust military leader Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. Alejandro Serrano Caldera, the ambassador of Nicaragua, which called for an emergency Security Council meeting, retorted that ``the United States has no legal or ethical right to intervene in other countries' affairs.'' Speaking outside the council chambers, Serrano Caldera said the Panamanian people ``have the right to self-determination; this action by the United States violated the sovereignty of the Panamanian people.'' ``We want the council to call for an immediate withdrawal of the U.S. troops,'' Serrano Caldera said, speaking in Spanish. Nicaragua's U.N. mission announced the Sandinista government had declared a national alert and mobilized troops against what President Daniel Ortega said was Washington's ``serious threat against Nicaragua.'' Security Council ambassadors met individually in the morning and scheduled private consultations for the rest of the day; it was unclear whether a formal, public meeting would be held. Pickering said the United States had the right to intervene under Article 51 of the U.N. Charter, ``which provides for the use of armed force to defend a country, to defend our interests and our people, it's the so-called `self-defense article.''' Panamanian soldiers shot and killed a U.S. Marine officer at a roadblock on Saturday night. Panama's declaration last week that a ``state of war'' existed with the United States and ``the attacks on our citizens over the weekend are several of the things which the president has cited which required us to move in self-defense,'' Pickering said. Article 51 of the Charter permits the use of ``individual or collective self-defense if an armed attack occurs against a member of the United Nations, until the Security Council has taken measures necessary to maintain international peace and security.'' Pickering said he was talking with council members and favored more consultations before any public meeting is held. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said President Bush ordered U.S. troops to seize Noriega and bring him to the United States for trial on drug trafficking charges. Secretary of State James A. Baker III informed Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the military moves at 2 a.m. Wednesday, said the U.N. chief's spokesman, Francois Giuliani. Perez de Cuellar is ``extremely concerned'' about the crisis, Giuliani said. Panama repeatedly has come before the Security Council to complain of allegedly provocative U.S. military maneuvers it said were intended to lay the groundwork for an invasion to topple the government. In August, Panamanian Foreign Minister Jorge Ritter asked the council to send military observers to his country to prevent the U.S. Army from goading confrontations as a pretext for armed intervention. U.N. military observers, said Ritter, ``will insure that the reality of the situation cannot be hidden and it will be recorded in the annals of history as a crime.'' However, Panama did not have any nation on the council introduce a resolution to send observers, a necessary step toward sending a mission. Panama said in April and August that the United States is trying to provoke confrontations in order to keep control of the Panama Canal. Under a 1977 treaty, the United States is to turn over control of the canal to Panama at the end of 1999.
